Award.AwardTitle: Data Matters: Meetings of the U.S. National Committee for CODATA

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research data and information are critical parts of science. As science becomes more international, so does the need for active engagement internationally. The Council on Data for Science and Technology, as part of the International Council on Science, provides a platform for top-down planning, development and integration of data, data standards, and data access.


The National Academy of Sciences, NAS, is the adhering body to the International Council for Science and its Committee on Data for Science and Technology (CODATA). The U.S. CODATA, housed at the NAS, represents the U.S. data community and coordinates with CODATA's
international activities. The U.S. CODATA will participate in the International Council for Science and conduct a meeting of U.S. CODATA to identify further activities. These might include consensus studies, workshops, conferences, and other activities within its mission to advance data management challenges in the U.S.; fulfill a convening function to encourage and facilitate collaboration across disciplines, sectors, and nations with regard to common interests in research data and information activities; monitor, assess, and contribute to the development of U.S. government and research community positions on research data and information programs and policies; and broadly disseminate and communicate the results of the U.S. CODATA's activities to the U.S. scientific community and to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Committee on Data for Science and Technology (CODATA) is an interdisciplinary Scientific Committee of the International Science Council (ISC). It involves many national members in issues of data science and data policy, including quality, reliability, management, and accessibility. National Academy of Sciences’ representation on behalf of the United States is done through the U.S. National Committee for CODATA (U.S. CODATA) and allows for stable participation at both scientific and governance levels. This project allowed the payment of dues and communications with CODATA, which in turn provides opportunities for professional development for U.S. scientists at all career levels. U.S. data scientists and specialists are active in the governance and activities of CODATA.

U.S. CODATA/Board on Research Data and Information (BRDI)’s annual meeting was held in November 2017 to discuss progress in current and future activities with the participation of CODATA U.S. leaders, members of the Board, and representatives from NSF and several other government agencies. It also organized and hosted “International Coordination for Science Data Infrastructure,“ a symposium held at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, D.C. on November 2, 2017. The Proceedings of a Workshop-in Brief can be freely downloaded at https://www.nap.edu/catalog/25015.

U.S. CODATA also participated as co-organizer of a workshop entitled “Challenges in Managing Digital Objects in an Expanding Science Ecosystem,” held at the NIH’s National Library of Medicine on November 15, 2017. An open access scientific paper describing the event was published in the Data Science Journal (http://doi.org/10.5334/dsj-2018-016).

Through its well-attended activities and freely accessible products, U.S. CODATA highlights U.S. advances on data issues in an international context and helps to involve U.S. stakeholders in government, academia, industry, and non-profits in activities that range from technical workshops and symposia to the discussion of issues at the forefront of data science.
